commit.message:
Fix CMake builds using MSVC's Clang frontend (#15)

Currently, nsync suppresses a number of MSVC warnings in order to keep
the build-log size manageable.  The warning suppressions are added if
the operating system is detected as Windows, which is no longer quite
correct - MSVC has a Clang frontend now that does not understand the
"/wdXXXX" switch format.  Instead, it treats those flags as files to
compile.

This commit fixes the issue by defining those warning suppressions if
the compiler ID is MSVC, which is the correct check.

It also switches from "add_definitions" to "add_compile_options", which
is a little more correct.  The scoping rules are the same, but
"add_definitions" is intended more for preprocessor definitions.

Fix CMake builds using MSVC's Clang frontend (#15)

Currently, nsync suppresses a number of MSVC warnings in order to keep
the build-log size manageable.  The warning suppressions are added if
the operating system is detected as Windows, which is no longer quite
correct - MSVC has a Clang frontend now that does not understand the
"/wdXXXX" switch format.  Instead, it treats those flags as files to
compile.

This commit fixes the issue by defining those warning suppressions if
the compiler ID is MSVC, which is the correct check.

It also switches from "add_definitions" to "add_compile_options", which
is a little more correct.  The scoping rules are the same, but
"add_definitions" is intended more for preprocessor definitions.

commit.message:
Update nsync Thread Sanitizer (TSan) annotations.

I had previously added some TSan dynamic annotations to nsync to avoid TSan
race warnings.  However, depending on whether gcc or clang was used, and
depending on the version of clang used, TSan race warnings could be reported on
the nsync tests.

When TSan is in used, this change adds a call to AnnotateRWLockAcquired just
after each nsync mu acquistion, and a call AnnotateRWLockReleased just before
each release.  Additionally, AnnotateRWLockCreate is called at each mu
creation.  (nsync mutex destruction is inferred when memory is recycled.)
Macros are used so that these additional calls are not introduced when TSan is
not in use.

All tests now pass without warnings in TSan mode in both clang and gcc,
including in all the versions that previously reported warnings.

In addition, the version number is incremented, and there are a few minor
whitespace changes to make the TSan annotations conform the the project's
whitespace conventions.
Update the VERSION number.
add loongarch support (#11)

commit.message:
In nsync, avoid an ABSL depepdency for TSAN annotations.

The code used to use ABSL macros for TSAN annotations that suppress warnings.

This was a problem because:
- ABSL is changing the names of the macros(!), and the team seems intent on
  forcing clients to make the incompatible change, even if the users of those
  clients have not yet switched to a suifficiently recent version of ABSL.  And
  they are doing this despite their (apparently false) claim of a 5-year API
  stability guarantee.
- The code had hard-wired a header file path that was wrong for most users,
  effectively preventing them from running with TSAN.
- The conditional compilation to detect TSAN worked only for clang, and not for
  gcc, even though gcc supports TSAN.

This change drops the ABSL dependency so there's no header file to include;
it uses conditional compilation that detects TSAN on moth gcc and clang; and
it uses the gcc/clang annotation routines directly.

The version number is also increased.
fix typo (#8)

Suppress compiler warnings on newer compilers that have additional checks.

GCC 8.0 in C++ mode introduced a warning if memset() is used to zero a struct,
even if it POD.  This causes the compiler to be chatty if nsync is build using g++.
Most of the changes are to cast the pointer argument to memset() to "void *" to avoid
the warning.

GCC 8.0 in C++ mode also started warning if a C-style cast changed the
"constness" of the data.  I'd accidentally done this in testing/testing.c; now fixed.

NetBSD has started using C99-style designated initializers in the standard pthread
initializer constants even if using C89; clang 8.0 warns about this.  This
change turns the warning off in the netbsd/clang Makefiles.

If possible, avoid C++11 thread_local for TSD, even in C++11 builds.
And when it is unavaoidable, attempt to handle the possibility of
C++11's per_thread_waiter destructor being called multiple times
on the same variable.

Previously, if a C++11 build of nsync was requested, we would use
C++11 thread_local to achieve the effects of
pthread_key_create()'s destructor argument; that is, to invoke
cleanup when a thread exits.

Unfortunately,
a) C++11 specifies that the destructors of static thread_local
   variables for the thread calling exit() are called before other static
   destructors are called.  See
   https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/utility/program/exit
   [Strangely, it doesn't destruct all variables, which makes you wonder why it
   bothers to destruct any, given that destructing any is dangerous.]

b) nsync can be pulled into an address space multiple times via
   multiple shared libraries into which nsync has been linked.

Even (a) alone is dangerous: imagine that a programmer uses a thread_local
variable from another static variable's destructor.

When coupled with (b), various implementation behaviours become conceivable.
For example, it's possible that an implementation could cause the same
thread_local variable to be desructed repeatedly, once by each copy of the
code pulled into the address space.

This change does several things.  The first two are related directly to the
issue described above.  The remainder were found during testing.

1) Uses pthread_key_create/pthread_getspecific/pthread_setspecific
   whenever possible, to avoid the use of thread_local.
   That's the version in nsync/platform/posix/src/per_thread_waiter.c.
   On Windows, we use the code that simulates pthread_key_create etc.

2) If the C++11 version is used, it will try to defend itself
   against the destructor being called twice, assuming that's
   a potential issue.  That's the version in
   nsync/platform/c++11/src/per_thread_waiter.cc

3) It fixes a bug in platform/win32/src/pthread_key_win32.cc.
   Previously the code could try to run a null destructor.  This
   could never happen in practice, because the library never sets
   a null destructor, but it's good to fix.

4) It casts the pointer passed to Windows'
   InterlockedCompareExchange().  Different compilers on Windows
   have different ideas about type compatibility with uint32_t.

See
  https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/31301

Introduce an implementation of nsync's internal semaphore that uses
MacOS Grand Central Dispatch primitives.
For documentation of that primitive, see:
    https://developer.apple.com/documentation/dispatch/1452955-dispatch_semaphore_create
    https://developer.apple.com/documentation/dispatch/1453087-dispatch_semaphore_wait
    https://developer.apple.com/documentation/dispatch/1452919-dispatch_semaphore_signal

This seamaphore is faster for wakeups on the Mac than the implementation using
the pthread API.  For example, for the ping_pong benchmark (which just does
waits and wakeups back and forth between threads) for mu_wait and
cv_wait:
   Benchmark pingpong_test                                  ops     time   ops/sec  time/op
   ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
pthread implementation:
   benchmark_ping_pong_mu                                359375    3.66s   9.8e+04  10.17us
   benchmark_ping_pong_mu_cv                             359375    3.83s   9.4e+04  10.66us
gcd_implementation:
   benchmark_ping_pong_mu                                359375    2.54s   1.4e+05   7.08us
   benchmark_ping_pong_mu_cv                             359375    2.51s   1.4e+05   6.98us

Create a Makefile that uses the new semaphore implementation on the Mac, for testing.

In cv_test.c and mu_wait_test.c, modify the way values are converted between
pointers and integers for the producer/consumer performance test to avoid
warning on some compilers about pointer arithmetic on the nil pointer.

Patch 1 (#7)

* Update BUILD

Our team at Arm Inc. tested Tensorflow that has a dependency on nsync. We found that the cpu type has to be "aarch64" instead of "arm" for correct compilation on aarch64 servers.

* Update bazel_BUILD

Our team at Arm Inc. tested Tensorflow that has a dependency on nsync. We found that the cpu type has to be "aarch64" instead of "arm" for correct compilation on aarch64 servers.

Separate C and C++ libraries and CMake fixes (#6)

* CMake: version sofiles and respect libdir

Version the libraries like libnsync.so.1.20.0 and set the symlinks
properly. The version is taken from the VERSION file in the root, it
should be updated with new releases. The minimum is kept CMake version
is kept at 2.8 but >=3.0 is strongly recommended. Since the minimum is
<3.0, policy CMP0048 must be set to NEW.

64bit distros use /usr/lib64 not /usr/lib so this needs to be
configurable as well.

The source properties for C++ are set outside of enabling the tests
otherwise building the C++ library with tests disabled fails.

Signed-off-by: Jason Zaman <jason@perfinion.com>

* CMake: add separate libnsync_cpp library target so C/C++ do not conflict

The libraries should be named differently otherwise they cannot be
installed together on the system. libnsync.so is the C library.
libnsync_cpp.so is the C++ library. The header files for both are
identical.

Both are built from the same source files so the C++ source files must
be copied so that the source file property LANGUAGE can be set. The copy
is done during build so the configure step does not need to be re-done
after any code changes. Per-OS settings are now all done together and
then two functions set the C / C++ properties on the build targets.

The C library is the recommended one and the C++ library takes
significantly longer to build and test so it is possible to only build
and install only the C library.

$ mkdir build; cd build
$ cmake ..
$ make nsync
$ make test_c
$ make install

Will build and install only the C library. make all will still build
both libraries like normal. There are also test_c / test_cpp targets
to run only C/C++ tests.

Signed-off-by: Jason Zaman <jason@perfinion.com>

assembler atomics for s390x, RISC-V, and m68k; fix typos in README.

This change:

Fixes various typoes in the README file.

Provides make build directories for s390x
(builds/s390x.linux.gcc builds/s390x.linux.gcc.atm-asm)

Provides platform/m68k/cputype.h and platform/m68k/src/nsync_atm_m68k.s (which
works on 68020 and above).

Provides platform/riscv/cputype.h and platform/riscv/src/nsync_atm_riscv.s
(which should work for both riscv32 and riscv64).

Provides platform/s390x/src/nsync_atm_s390x.s

Fixeds tools/detect.c to allow for __riscv and __m68k__ macros, and to to
detect s390x before s390.

commit.message:
Provide a default "posix" build for cmake in nsync.

This works on platforms like cygwin, for example.
allow empty default CPU architecture

Use futex to implement low-level semphore on Linux,
even when building in portable C++11 mode.

Previously in C++11 builds in Linux, I had used a C++11 condition variable to
implement the semaphore that nsync uses to block.
However, for some reason the condition variable in Linux' C++11 library is
extremely and surprisingly slow:  perhaps ten times slower than the basic
operating system primitive.

This change uses the underlying primitive (futex) directly,
to avoid this performance problem.

This is fixed in the Makefile, cmake and bazel builds.
Allow consumers of nsync to turn off test creation

Add a generic_unix Makefile to nsync, plus cleanups.

This change adds a "generic_unix" Makefile to nsync.
The idea is that if you cd to nsync/builds/generic_unix
on most Unix-like platforms, it's sufficient to type:
	make

If you use a special compiler, or a cross-compiler
	make CC=<compiler>

That works because all the information about the
platform is derived from the compiler's beahviour.

This works as follows:
	The Makefile invokes another Makefile via a script detect.sh which
	detects the target platform type and passes appropriarte flags to the
	second "make" invocation.

	The platform detection is done by running a file "detect.c" through the
	compiler's C preprocessor, to get the value of four parameters:
		the compiler type (e.g., gcc)
		the OS type (e.g., netbsd)
		the CPU architecture type (e.g., mips)
		the target language (e.g., c, c11, c++, c++11)
	The script sets the Makefile parameters based on those
	detected values.

builds/generic_unix/Makefile
builds/generic_unix/Makefile.helper
	Initial and secondary Makefiles for generic_unix build

tools/detect.sh
	Platform detection script.

tools/detect.c
	C preprocessed file for platform detection.

tools/mkdep.sh
	The compiler may be a cross-compiler, so it may not be able to run
	mkdep.c.  This does the same thing as a shell script.
	(mkdep.c is still needed for Windows, however.)

tools/run_tests.sh
	A shell-script version of run_tests.  Again, a shell script to allow it
	tio be used when a cross-compiler is in use.  It has an extra flag to
	define an intermediate programme to run the cross-compiled tests
	(perhaps removely or via an interpreter).
	The Makefiles do not yet use this script.

Changes to allow additional compilers:

platform/pcc/compiler.h
platform/tendracc/compiler.h
tools/mkmakefile.sh
	Add support for pcc and tendracc.

builds/x86_32.linux.clang/Makefile
builds/x86_32.linux.gcc/Makefile
builds/x86_32.linux.tcc/Makefile
	Add -lrt on linux patforms which cometimes find clock_gettime() in
	librt.

platform/num_time/nsync_time_init.h
platform/num_time/src/time_rep.c
nsync/public/nsync_time_internal.h
	Allow nsync_time to be a numeric type (typically an nit64_t or a double),
	rather than a struct.
	This allows the library to be used even with early compilers
	that cannot pass or return structs.

Code cleanups:

platform/posix/make.common
	Terminate for-loops promptly when a command in the loop fails.
	Use "set -x" to print each command run in the loop.

testing/cv_test.c
testing/mu_wait_test.c
	Make types in pointer artimetic clearer.

testing/once_test.c
testing/wait_test.c
	Avoid variable shadowing (first was shadowing ott, second w).

testing/testing.c
	Remove a "break" from a loop, saving a few lines.

Bazel and cmake support for FreeBSD in nsync.

Bazel BUILD file
- add select() clausesx for FreeBSD.

CMakeLists.txt
- fix the FreeBSD source list.  Also fix for NetBSD and OpenBSD; they are the same.

Add a Makefile for C++11 build on FreeBSD.

Usually, the tests can be linked by invoking the compiler as though it were the
linker.  But with clang on FreeBSD, the "-x c++" used to tell the compiler to
treat the .c files as C++ also causes .o files to be treated as C++ source
files.  So this change also modifies make.common to make it possible to use a
different command for the linker.

Fix a bug in mkdep.c, which would not recognize the suffix .CC as C++.

Support x86_32 in bazel BUILD file.

This change supports x86_32 in the bazel BUILD file.
Currently, bazel's name for x86_32 is "piii".

Fix potential undefined behaviour found with -fsanitize=function.

In two source files I was calling functions whose pointers have type
    void (*) (nsync_mu *)
via function pointers with type
    void (*) (void *)

While that will work on almost all implementations,
it is not required to work by the C and C++ standards.

This change introduces local functions to do the conversion in a safe way
(the conversion is needed to implement the generic CV wait operation).

The new code involves an extra function call, but this is not on a fast path:
it happens when waiting on a condition variable, which will usually involve a
trip through the kernel.

Rename BUILD.bazel to bazel_BUILD to prevent bazel using it as a BUILD file.

I had used the name "BUILD.bazel" for the name of an inactive copy of a bazel
BUILD file that should not be interpreted as a BUILD file in its existing
directory.  (The file is copied to BUILD at the root of the nsync tree to make
an open source, bazel-buildable version of the tree.)

Alas, bazel will interpret "BUILD.bazel" as though it were "BUILD" because:
1) when using the "makefile" build,
      tensorflow/contrib/makefile/download_dependencies.sh
   puts a copy of the nsync tree inside the tensorflow tree
   (under tensorflow/contrib/makefile/downloads), and
2) various build rules in the tensorflow tree use recursive glob syntax to
   refer to entire trees, and some thus include everything within
   tensorflow/contrib/makefile/downloads.
As a result, if someone first uses download_dependencies.sh, and then invokes
bazel on a rule that uses a recursive glob that covers the downsloads
directory, bazel will parse all the BUILD files within all the downloaded
packages(!), and thus fail if any contain BUILD (or BUILD.bazel) files not
valid in their contexts.

This change renames BUILD.bazel to bazel_BUILD.  Bazel doesn't seem
to recognize that name yet.

Create the library libnsync.a on UNIX-like machines in addition to nsync.a

Machines with UNIX-like linkers look the name lib<foo>.a when
invoked with the -lfoo flag, so we now produce the library with the name
libnsync.a.   The old name is still generated for backwards compatibility;
eventually the old name may go away.

Portability fixes and workarounds for s390x, MacOS, and C11 atomics.

- Add s390x to bazel's build file.
  Alas, Bazel has a half-baked approach to platform dependent builds, and
  requires you to deduce the operating system and compiler from the CPU type.
  So we need to list the s390x CPU explicitly, just to encode that this
  platform is "linux" and "gcc".
  The header file platform/s390x/cputype.h tells the builds
  that the s390x has implicit memory barriers on its loads and stores.
  For the moment, there's no assembly lanmguage version of the atomics, so this
  platform will work only with compilers/languages or operating systems that
  provide atomics.

- Apple didn't test some of their C++11 includes, such as
	#include <mutex>
  in some of the OS versions, such as Sierra.  To avoid a compile-time error,
  it's necessary to define "_DARWIN_C_SOURCE" on such platforms.  And since we
  don't know which version of the system the user will be using, we define it
  on all version of MacOS, and in all of the Makefile, CMakeLists.txt, and
  bazel BUILD file in the cases when compiling with a C++11 compiler instead of
  a C compiler.

- Apple deprecated their MacOS atomics library, even though they only just made
  the replacement (C11's stdatomic.h) work correctly.  So very recent versions
  give errors about the former being deprecated, and versions that are only a
  little older (and which the developer might still be reasonably using) can't
  use the alternative.  We work around this by ignoring the deprecation for now
  by turning off the deprecation check.
  This affects the MacOS Makefiles.

- Apple have implemented clock_gettime() on later versions.
  This is accommodated with a #if in platform/macos/platform.h.

Other issues encountered during these fixes:
- Use a clang C11 build to test the C11 atomics.  It's closer to the standard
  than the gcc C11.  This adds a few files of the form
  builds/*.clang.atm-c11/Makefile

- To allow clang to be used more (even with Makefiles designed for gcc), add
  -Wno-unneeded-internal-declaration.  clang is pickier about unused static
  variables than gcc, and the obvious implmentation technique for static
  assertions in C90 involves static variables that typically are unused.  So
  turn off this check in some Makefiles.

- clang's stdatomic.h adheres to the standard in requiring a non-const pointer
  on atomic loads(!).  So a cast is needed in platform/c11/atomic.h to remove
  the const property.

- Bug fix:  public/nsync_atomic.h was using uint_least32_t instead of
  atomic_uint_least32_t for C11 atomics.  This error was caught using clang
  for C11 atomics.

Fix nsync's cmake build for MacOS.

Previously, I had just guessed at the MacOS cmake configuration; I never tried
it because I didn't expect people to user cmake on MacOS.  But apparently some
people use cmake rather than bazel to build tensorflow on MacOS, which means
this needs to work.

There were two problems:
- In the C++ build case, I had neglected to add the "platform/posix" directory
  to the include path.  This is needed to pick up the time representation.
- In both the C and C++ build cases, I had failed to include the
  clock_gettime.c and nsync_semaphore_mutex.c modules.  The first is needed
  because MacOS (or at least some versions) doesn't provide clock_gettime().
  The second is needed because some semaphore implementation is required---I
  had just failed to pick one.

Tested by building both using C++ and C on a Mac.

Update Bazel BUILD file to make nsync build on Windows with Bazel

The BUILD file previously did not support Windows because bazel did
not support Windows.  Bazel's Windows support is now in beta,
so things may yet change, but this seems to work.

Bug fix for nsync_cv transfer of waiters to the mutex.

When a condition variable wakeup occurs and the associated mutex is held, the
intent is that waiters are transferred to the mutex waiter queue rather than
being woken only to block anew on the mutex.

There were at least three bugs in this code:
- I used the wrong condition for "just one waiter in the list".
  My expression used the condition for a raw circular list (first_waiter !=
  next), but the API to the list returns NULL when asked for the next element
  from the last, so it should be (next != NULL).
- Setting the designated waker bit is more subtle here than I assumed;
  the easiest fix is to forgo the opimization in this path.  After all,
  condition variable wakeup implies that some thread had blocked,
  which is a fairly heavyweight operation, so the optmization is not
  worth as much as a fraction.
- Transfer to the mutex queue is also subtle if the mutex was not held by some
  thread.  It may be possible to perform such a transfer once the other
  two issues are fixed, perhaps by checking that there is already a designated
  waker, but it makes the code harder to think about.  So I forgo this
  optimization also.
Besides subtlety, another reason to avoid heroic optimizations in the case
where the mutex is not held is that I wouldn't recommend that anyone normally
signal with the mutex not held anyway, since it's unsafe in some cases (e.g.,
imagine the object containing the mutex is reference counted, and the count is
protected by that mutex, so the object may be freed by the time of the signal).
That bias in expectations is part of why I missed this in testing in the first
place.

This change fixes the queue length test, allows transfer only if the mutex is
actually held, and does not attempt the optimization of setting the designated
waker bit.
